newsitem.title: UK: Gold static amid May Day holidays, awaits New York.
newsitem.headline: Gold static amid May Day holidays, awaits New York.

text.p: Gold was markedly quiet at easier levels on Thursday with most of Europe was shut for May Day holidays, but dealers expected some thrills from New York.
Precious metals saw some lending into platinum that eased tight liquidity conditions, while silver shared gold's lethargy.
Bullion fixed a touch easier at $339.55 an ounce, while spot gold was quoted at $339.60/$339.90, down 70 cents.
Feelings toward gold remained overwhelmingly bearish with fears of future central bank sales keeping bullion's prospects strictly capped under $350.00, dealers said.
The dollar, rushing to multi-year highs, added to the pressure.
But dealers said the market could manage to glean some support and crawl back above $340.00 following Wednesday's blip to $341.25, which was subsequently negated at the close.
"It bounced from the $338-$339 level every time it got there. I think it might be edging its way back above $340 today," said one London dealer.
Strong U.S. GDP, pointing to an inflation pick-up, jolted Comex gold futures out of their listless mood, but only briefly, after Tuesday's benign U.S. figures favoured bonds instead.
"For the time being we are stuck in the $336-$341 range," said gold dealer Morris Emmanuel at Swiss-based Socofinance.
The market will be searching for new clues on the likelihood of U.S. rate hikes from Friday's key non-farm payrolls.
Most technical analysts maintain a bearish stance on gold while a downtrend line extending from $363.95 remained in place.
"Initially place (support) at $338.50, which if breached would suggest a target of $330," said analyst Martin Squires of brokers Rudolf Wolff.
On the upside, resistance was heavy at $342.50. In the unlikely event of a rally beyond that point, gold would be faced with the rock-solid barrier of $345.00, analysts said.
Platinum forward rates softened early with one-month leasing quoted at eight percent from 9-10 previously.
"Somebody has lent the metal out," said one dealer.
But last month's activity on protracted delays in Russian supplies was receding.
"The market seems to have lost its way a little bit. These stories are getting a bit stale after a while," said the dealer.
Spot platinum was quoted 40 cents higher at $372.00/$373.00, while palladium shed $1.00 to $155.25/$156.25.
Silver stood three cents down at $4.67/$4.69 and its potential gains were seen limited to $4.73 for now.
-- Clelia Oziel, London Newsroom +44-171-542 8071
